channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. & A.: Kung Tsui-chang on Life as the Heir to Confucius
item.description: Kung Tsui-chang, a 39-year-old businessman in Taiwan who is the 79th-generation direct descendant of Confucius, discusses what it was like growing up in the family of such a famous figure.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Kung Tsui-chang, right, at a ceremony in the Confucius Temple in Taipei, Taiwan, on Sept. 28, 2007, honoring the ancient Chinese philosopher.

item.title: French Authorities Hunt What May Be a Wildcat Near Disneyland
item.description: A large animal on the loose on the outskirts of Paris is not a tiger but another species of feline, news agencies reported.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Olivier Lejeune/Le Parisien/Maxppp, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Officials estimated that a large wildcat on the loose on the outskirts of Paris weighed as much as 150 pounds, based on the size of its tracks.

item.title: E.U. Accuses Starbucks and Netherlands of Making Unfair Tax Deal
item.description: The arrangement helped lower taxes for the coffee company, creating unfair advantages over other European Union countries, authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A branch of Starbucks in central London. Starbucks announced in April that it was moving its European headquarters to Britain.

item.title: The Tax Attraction Between Starbucks and the Netherlands
item.description: As global authorities ramp up efforts to close tax loopholes, companies are lobbying against proposed reforms.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Microsoft's headquarters in Luxembourg. American companies are fighting efforts in Europe to reverse favorable tax deals.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: In Soft-Spoken Romanian Prosecutor, Some See an ‘Earthquake’
item.description: Those caught in the sights of Laura Codruta Kovesi, who, as head of Romania’s anticorruption agency, is leading a vigorous drive against graft, denounce her as a Stalinist.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Cristian Movila for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laura Codruta Kovesi, 41, leads Romania’s National Anticorruption Directorate.

item.title: Ashraf Ghani to Meet with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan will meet with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and Pakistani military officials to discuss curbing terrorism on the shared border.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: China’s Rise as Arms Supplier Is Put on Display
item.description: The world’s fourth-largest exporter of arms is now encouraging smaller private domestic companies to enter the field.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINA LARSON
item.media:description: A model poses next to missiles from the "Beijing Symbol of Power Technology Development Company," at Airshow China.

item.title: India Sterilization Deaths Linked to Pills Tainted With Rat Poison, Officials Say
item.description: Officials in Chhattisgarh state issued an urgent warning to practitioners to cease distribution of the antibiotic ciprofloxacin after at least 15 deaths were linked to it.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: A patient who suffered complications from a sterilization procedure was in the intensive care unit of a local hospital on Friday.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon Becomes Leader of Scottish National Party
item.description: Ms. Sturgeon moved into the job after 10 years as deputy leader and immediately suggested that the party might seek a new referendum on independence.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: In Myanmar, Obama Affirms Support for Democracy
item.description: President Obama met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in a show of support for Myanmar’s reform process, despite evidence of the nation’s backsliding.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader.

item.title: Sweden Says Mystery Vessel in Its Waters Was a Foreign Submarine
item.description: Although the craft was never found, and numerous reports at the time said it was Russian, the authorities did not blame any particular country for the intrusion.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Rescuing Protest Artwork From Hong Kong’s Streets
item.description: Art lovers and historians are scrambling to find ways to preserve the explosion of art that has arisen in public spaces occupied by pro-democracy demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU
item.media:description: Three artworks satirically depicting Chinese leaders as democracy supporters. From left, Deng Xiaoping, Mao Zedong and Jiang Zemin.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Gold Bars, Moldy Cash and a Chinese Official’s Mom Who Can Explain It All
item.description: Anticorruption investigators say they found in a family home some 120 million renminbi in cash, 37 kilograms of gold bars and ownership documents for 68 homes, including seven in expensive parts of Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: "It was too much trouble going to the bank to get money," said the mother of the fallen official Ma Chaoqun.

item.title: Obama Reaffirms Support for Myanmar’s Democracy Leader
item.description: President Obama met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi on Friday in a show of support for Myanmar’s reform process, despite evidence of backsliding in its transition from military dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: North Korea to Send Senior Envoy to Russia
item.description: North Korea is seeking to improve its ties with Russia as a possible counterbalance to China.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Edward J. Ramotowski on Implications of the New U.S.-China Visa Policy
item.description: The State Department official discusses how the new visa policy came about, what remains to be done and where the United States stands to benefit.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry issued one of the first 10-year visas to a Chinese applicant, Yang Bo, at the United States Embassy in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: South Korea Suspends Asiana Flights Between Incheon and San Francisco
item.description: The penalty is for the 2013 crash that killed three passengers, the first fatal airliner disaster in the United States in more than four years.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Lyon Journal: Brushing Off a French Stigma That Doggie Bags Are for Beggars
item.description: Authorities in Lyon, France, are promoting doggie bags, long stigmatized as a sign of poverty, in local restaurants to curb food waste.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Marlene Awaad for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yoann Blanc, owner and chef of La Tête de Lard, a typical “bouchon” Lyonnais restaurant, showed off his form of a doggie bag.

item.title: Sudan and Rebels Under Pressure to Find Path to Peace
item.description: Talks that began Wednesday are seen as part of a comprehensive national dialogue that includes finding a way to greater political freedom.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Nowhere to Run in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: A cease-fire has been in effect in the rebel areas of eastern Ukraine since September, but severe depopulation is a clear sign that war is once again looming.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy in Ilovaisk, Ukraine, next to his house, which was destroyed in a Russian offensive this summer. A cease-fire on Sept. 5 has done little to curb the violence.

item.title: U.N. Commission Presses U.S. on Torture
item.description: A United Nations panel that monitors compliance with an antitorture treaty expressed skepticism Thursday about American law enforcement and national security practices.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Iraq and Kurds Reach Deal on Oil Exports and Budget Payments
item.description: A standoff began earlier this year when Kurdish officials angered Baghdad by exporting oil produced in their region directly to Turkey and not through the Iraqi Oil Ministry.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gas burn-off and oil tanks at the northern oil fields in Kirkuk, Iraq. Kurdish officials angered Baghdad by exporting oil produced in their region directly to Turkey.

item.title: Comet Landing Bumpier Than Initially Thought
item.description: The European Space Agency lander is sitting in a skewed position on the comet’s surface, compromising some aspects of the $1.75 billion Rosetta mission.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: A two-image panorama taken by the Philae lander from the surface of Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko.

item.title: Kerry Is Optimistic After Meeting Over Holy Site in Jerusalem
item.description: John Kerry met with the leaders of Jordan, Israel and the Palestinian Authority to discuss the site known to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary and to Jews as Temple Mount.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: After an Attack on U.S. Sailors, 12 Suspects Are Charged and Released
item.description: Twelve Turks arrested in Istanbul in connection with a videotaped assault on three visiting American sailors were charged on Thursday with insult, inflicting injury and violating Turkey’s protest and rally law, but all of them were released, Turkey’s Anadolu news agency reported.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
